conclusion: Area of coil ABCO = 0.4 m², Magnetic induction intensity B = 0.1 T (along the positive x-axis), The coil rotates 60° downward around the z-axis
The magnetic flux Φ through a coil is given by: Φ = B · A · cos(θ)
The coil ABCO lies in the xz-plane with normal vector pointing along the y-axis.

premise: The coil ABCO lies in the xz-plane with normal vector pointing along the y-axis. The magnetic field is along the x-axis.
conclusion: The angle between the field and the normal vector is 90°.

premise: B = 0.1 T, A = 0.4 m², angle θ = 90°
conclusion: Initial flux Φ₁ = B · A · cos(90°) = 0.1 T · 0.4 m² · 0 = 0 Wb

premise: The coil rotates 60° downward around the z-axis.
conclusion: After rotation, the normal vector makes an angle of (90° - 60°) = 30° with the x-axis.

premise: B = 0.1 T, A = 0.4 m², angle θ = 30°
conclusion: Final flux Φ₂ = B · A · cos(30°) = 0.1 T · 0.4 m² · 0.866 = 0.03464 Wb
Change in flux = Φ₂ - Φ₁ = 0.03464 Wb - 0 Wb = 0.03464 Wb
The change in magnetic flux through the coil is 0.0346 Wb.
